Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Adaptive and Autonomous Energy Management on a Sensor Network Using Aerial Robots

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research introduces novel recharging systems and algorithms to supplement existing systems and lead to autonomous, sustainable energy management on sensor networks. Applications such as bridge fault detection that rely on sensor networks operating away from buildings often lack energy for long-term monitoring. In these scenarios traditional recharging methods (e.g. solar panels) are unavailable or cannot provide sufficient energy (e.g. at night). To achieve this, the research has three key components. The first component develops an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) to wirelessly recharge sensor nodes, a localization system based on magnetic field intensity, and autonomous control algorithms that optimize power transfer. Based on this system, the second part develops online algorithms for UAV trajectory optimization in systems with multiple UAVs as well as distributed algorithms that induce energy deficits in a subset of nodes to enable efficient recharging. Finally, the third component provides models and distributed algorithms to predict future energy recharging and usage for sensor nodes.

This research impacts a range of societal, educational, and scientific topics. This project addresses a critical national need of enabling regular monitoring of bridge integrity through autonomous, energy efficient sensor network and robot systems. Improving bridge fault detection is necessary given aging infrastructure and limited local budgets for performing such work through current manual visual inspection processes. Educationally, at the K-12 level, this provides demos and workshops to enhance existing programs, encouraging young students (especially women) to pursue STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop novel recharging systems and algorithms for autonomous, sustainable energy management on sensor networks.  This work divides into two key sections: (1) Design, implementation, and algorithms for a novel wireless power recharging system utilizing Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) and (2) Algorithms and policies to balance power usage in order to increase the lifetime of the systems.  The results of our work improve environmental monitoring systems by allowing them to collect data longer through increased sensor lifetimes; we also improved the automated installation of sensors by enabling UAVs to identify the ground surface type where the node is installed.

For the first key section, we designed and implemented a wireless power recharging system that a UAV can carry to charge sensor nodes. The first part of this project developed a wireless power transfer board that can be carried by the UAV, which enables outdoor and independent operation of the UAV.  Using this setup, the UAV can transfer 4W-10W while in flight and 20W when stationary over the target sensor node.

The second part of the wireless system explored how the UAV could align the recharging system with the sensor node.  The UAV uses GPS to get within 3-10m of the sensors (based on the GPS accuracy) and then switch to a different method to finish localizing and aligning.  We developed two different methods; one uses magnetic field sensors to measure the magnetic field created by the recharging system and the second uses a vision-based approach.  We identified the fact that the time it takes to localize the sensor from the UAV is the most critical factor in determining how many sensor nodes can be charged.  Given this, the vision-based system is slightly faster while both have similar error and power transfer rates, which makes either a reasonable solution.

The final part of the wireless system involved performing experiments to characterize the performance of the power transfer at different distances and through different materials. We examined the impact of embedding the receiving sensor in different materials, as it would be in field deployments. We found that the magnetic resonant power transfer system is not impacted by most non-metallic materials including plastic, wood, stone, and soil. This means, for instance, we can bury the receiving nodes in the ground to measure soil moisture or other ground parameters.

The second key section examined how to balance power usage to maximize the recharging benefit and increase system lifetimes.  We first focused on the UAV and developed a set of heuristic charging algorithms.  In particular, we examined hybrid algorithms that initially have no knowledge of the network energy levels, but over time learn the overall network energy level and estimate the energy level of individual nodes based on prior readings. Based on this knowledge, we then can select the best charging algorithm.  We implemented these algorithms on our indoor testbed consisting of a number of sensors and UAVs.

We next focused on the sensor network.  We developed a set of algorithms to modify how the different sensor nodes communicate and how to determine which node to recharge.  We implemented both our sink selection method and recharging policy on a sensor network.  This included resolving assumptions made in the simulations, including communication protocols and backoff policies.  The implementation confirmed the simulation results.

In addition to our original goals, we also developed a sensor node deployment system and classification algorithms that determines the type of surface the sensor is installed in. This is motivated by discussions with ecology and hydrology collaborators who were very excited about the possibilities of charging and collecting data from deployed sensors, but also identified that often deploying sensors is challenging and automated systems lack the ability to precisely install sensors in the correct soil times. We developed a UAV that can deploy sensors, but moreover, when it lands on a surface, it uses onboard sensor information to classify the type of surface (e.g. soil, grass, rock, etc.). This can augment existing vision-based classification systems that fail when, for instance, a rock is right under the surface of grass that would prevent automated installation of a soil moisture probe. We found that we can accurately classify the softness of the surface with 90% accuracy just based on accelerometer readings from landings. This is a significant result that will allow us to deploy, charge, and collect data from sensors that need to be installed in hard to access locations for long periods of time.
